reviewText:
I was suckered. I was curious as to whether this game would be the B-movie trash fest the makers claim it to be.... It's not. Let's start with the voice actiing... Oh god, the voice acting. Not only is it obvious the actors recorded their lines over a cheap microphone setup, but you also don't understand what they're saying half the time. Sometimes their accents become too thick to decypher (the main character's especially) or for some baffling reason the volume drops to a whisper. And why must my character freeze in place every time he starts talking with a person? Must he devote all his intellectual and physical prowess just to hold a simple conversation?

The AI isn't bad so much as very simple. Enemies just come running at you, spawning in from out of nowhere. (Think Aliens: Colonial Marines... better yet, don't) A few bright spots is that the gun play is all right, if nothing new, and the price isn't outrageous, although I'm probably not going to finish this game.

Buyer beware. The makers of this game try to hide the flaws in their work under a paper-thin veneer of poor humor and an 'Oh, you're not meant to take it so seriously' frontage. Do not expect much from this product. Don't even expect an options menu (cause there is none, seriously).

reviewText:
Into the Dark is a FPS horror game. The player takes control of Peter O’ Brannon, a detective who is sent to investigate the death of an elderly man in New England. Upon arriving at his cabin, you realise that all is not right and something sinister is going on.
The game makes a poor first impression. The game starts with ultra-low quality artwork and a surprisingly small amount of menu options, there is absolutely no configuration options. To configure the controls you have to edit a text file.
Gameplay consists of exploring bland locations, completing bland objectives and killing bland enemies. In order to complete the games puzzles, you often have to go back to rooms you have already explored to find that objects have magically spawned there. When you finally get past the obstacle, the game is kind enough to spawn an enemy directly behind you.
The graphics are bad. Into the Dark features completely antiquated visuals.
The voice acting for the game is beyond awful. For me it was nearly impossible to hear what is being said, it made it nearly impossible to follow the story.
If that is not enough, there are several technical issues; invisible walls block a door or you could stuck in such a wall. Loading up a saved game, starting a new level and even just doing nothing: all of them can cause crashes.
The best part in Into the Dark is that it includes the complete movie of Night of the Living Dead.
My advice take a look at other horror games. If you just want it for your collection wait for a big discount.

Sounds 2/10
Graphics 2/10
Gameplay 3/10
Atmosphere 3/10

Most of the puzzles are solved by pressing up against random objects in the room until you pick up the one you're looking for. Overall, the mechanics foiled what was probably otherwise a funny, kitschy game.

I bought this, m8s. In a bundle.
This is punk rock as sh*t

Depending on your view this can either be a good or a bad thing. I don't understand why everyone feels the need to point out that the developers said it was like a B-movie, but I'm going to do the same thing. In fact, I'm going to go further and say that it's more of a C-Movie. If you're not into underground gore flicks, you're probably not going to enjoy this game.

That genre translates well into this medium.

Not B-horror, but C-horror and no budget horror. Look up a movie called Zombie Bloodbath by a Director named Todd Sheets - I think it's up on Youtube for free right now along with some other stuff. That's the genre we're talking about here. The worst recordings, the bottom-of-barrel editing. This game has it all, but tops it off with the worst voice acting I've ever heard. There are two ways to do horrible voice acting - good or bad. In this case, it's pretty good.

I was asked to review the game...

Not by the developer, but it came up from someone I know, and it had been awhile since I've picked it up and played it - so WHY NOT, I figured, I'll play it again. Sometimes the humor in it can be way, way too much to deal with - that's just the nature of low budget/no budget movies put into a game.

The mini game doesn't work at all.

Never has.

The game is huge...

5 gigabytes is ridiculous for something like this.

If you want something a little different...

If you want something a little different, you should look elsewhere. If you want something a lot different, you might like this. As other people have said, this game feels a lot like something you yourself could make. In fact, it seems like something you yourself could make with very little effort - even though a lot of effort probably went into it. It's made with Game Guru, which I still maintain doesn't make a game bad - and it's pretty goofy. There are some really bizarre hiccups in the game that should really be ironed out, but if you can deal with closing and reopening a game a bunch of times, they're not too bad. It's okay - get it in a bundle, or something.

reviewText: True to its description, Into The Dark is to video gaming what B movies are to Hollywood. It's campy, littered with bad jokes, and bears an undercurrent of German jokes most Americans really won't get (and maybe aren't meant to). The puzzles are almost painfully simple, at least at first, and the setting is hastily thrown together (with love, I'm sure). But let's face it, you're not buying this game for triple A production value, famous voice actors, and revolutionary graphics -- you're buying it for the same reason you watched Mystery Science Theater 3000 and Iron Sky. It's goofy. It's fun. It's a playful little romp that will have you facepalming at times when you really should be pulling the trigger oh god it's the Nazi zombies again and you're dead and haven't saved the game for half an hour. Buy it. Play it. Put it down and never touch it again. And remember that no other game in your library, past or present, will give you an experience this uniquely nutty and bad.

I`ll be honest: I am a freeloader, one of those gready ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who lurke around ModDB and IndieDB and download every free game they can get and every interesting demo version published. I don´t buy more than 2-3 games per year, and the only reason I signed up with steam was the free key I got for having bought the Into the Dark Desura version almost a year ago.

And even I tell you, that this game is really great value for the little money asked.

First of all, forget all the morons who write bad reviews after playing less than 2 hours or having unlocked less than 40% of the achievements yet. Judging the game upon such impressions is like judging the old Star Wars movies upon the flying text in the begininng.

Second, you have to deal with the fact that the game won´t make it easy to change the controls if needed (but the default ones are good enough if you aren´t left-handed). And you have to deal with occasional crashes. These are not a big deal, as long as you exit the game after dying and follow the guidelines posted, you won´t have more than 2-3 crashes total. all of them on loading a new level. And the game creates savegames prior to the exits, so no big deal.

The game itself is weird, beautiful, excentric and strange. You have to look around carefully to get all the beautiful and fascinating details the developers crafted into the levels, and it´s totally worth it. The shooter part works really good as long as you have a fast PC, and some of the puzzles are quite interesting.

But, most of all, the ingame bonus content, the jokes, references, gags, political messages, slapstick moments and dialogues are over the top. Yes, Pete has a horrible accent, but that´s part of the game - and even part of two puzzles. Yes, the voice actors are amateurs, but they talk naturally to each other, instead of actors who read their lines alone in the studio. The visuals are ugly where showing ugly places, and stunning like the Playboy Mansion where beauty is asked for. From a technical point of view, the graphics are clearly above par.

You would have to be either stupid, ignorant or a heartless ♥♥♥♥♥ with no humor at all to find this game NOT amusing, entertaining and funny.

The Desura version was my best buy 2013, and the Ste4am version is indeed better.

If you have the wits and knowledge needed, and some good nerves for occasional crashes, it´s a best buy for sure.

reviewText:
You either love it or hate it - there is nothing in between.

The game shows several features that can annoy a player who expects the same behavior like in any other common game. As an example, instead of offering a settings menu, it simply draws its GFX settings from your graphics cards driver settings and the resolution from your displays native resolution. Clever idea, but if you want to override it, you have to go into the setup.ini hell (which is explained pretty well in the forums and the manual).
Enter is the default key for any environment interaction, so you have to let go your mosue to interact.
Stupid? On the contrary, that gives a good feeling that you are right now doing something in the game where you need both hands and cannot shoot in the meantime.

The developers also tricked many DRM- and Steam-opponents like me to hook up with steam by giving free Steam keys to Desura buyers. Not sure, if this is a good thing or something evil.

All those facts ignored, the game is still a matter of personal taste - and the intelligence of the player.
If you got the wits and the basic knowledge to at least most of the jokes, and if you are a player looking around carefully instead of rushing through the levels, there ain´t many games out there more entertaining than this one.

It´s filled with bad jokes, sinister jokes, references, political messages and a dense web of connections between all those, with so many details and depicted thoughts it can blow your mind.

While it looks ugly, the consistency of the art design in the levels is pretty good, and most textures are extremely detailled, from the technical point of view the graphics aint bad at all.

The crashes are annoying, but not game-breaking, as there is always a savegame to go on.

In the end, the conclusion will always be You either love it or hate it".

reviewText:
Choking hazard: Never play this game while eating or drinking. Both jump scares AND laughter could kill you. Sometimes at once.

Dislike hazard: Not suitable for casual gamers, comfort-zone-huggers, minors, linear-gameplay-lovers, hasty players or outright stupid people.

If you got a proper IQ, sinister humor, a basic knowledge of history and the patience to explore the environments, the game is awesome. Might take some levels to get into the mood, but then...

...trash, humor, horror, comedy, action, puzzles and more easter eggs than you can imagine. You name it, you get it. Also some nasty glitches.

EDIT 1:

The game gets better with each level, but it also shows some shortcomings in the process of progressing.
While the visual appearance becomes really nice from level 4 on, the backtracking is a little bit too much for my taste. If you use it for the neverending search for easter eggs and jokes, it seems fine, but if you want to go to the next level asap, it can get annoying. However, I love the amount of small details woven into the level design and the props you find there.
